newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soy products end sharply down on soybean drop.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soy products end sharply down on soybean drop.

text.p: CBOT soy product futures ended with heavy losses Friday after falling in tandem with soybeans, floor traders said.
CBOT soybeans settled sharply lower, with August and July registering double-digit losses on the close in response to a falling crushing pace and a favorable weather outlook.

Some traders had said the lower-than-expected weekly crush of 22.5 million bushels would be supportive to the products because it implied lower supplies. However, soyoil and soymeal weren't able to shake off the bearish influence of soybeans.

Commercial selling and lackluster demand continued to plague the soyoil market. Because South American soyoil holds a good-sized discount to U.S., all export demand has gone to Brazil and Argentina in recent months, cash traders said.
Domestic demand for soymeal is also tapering off somewhat as livestock dealers search for less expensive feeds such as grass, traders said.
CBOT soyoil futures ended 0.25 to 0.31 cent per lb lower, with July down 0.31 at 23.32. Soymeal ended down $1.00 to $5.00, with July down $3.60 at $280.20.
